description: Perhaps connected with Middle English gane, or possibly from Welsh geneu, Cornish ganau (“mouth”).
Probably a variant of gang, from Middle English gangen, from Old English gangan (“to step; walk; go”).

verbs.description: gan (third-person singular simple present gans, present participle gannin, simple past went, past participle gone)

examples: The one problem I had here was my broad Geordie accent which the teachers tried their hardest to make me lose. I couldn't understand their problem with it because I could understand myself. Whenever I told them, "Am gannin yem", they would say, "No, Christopher. It's not "am gannin yem", it's "I am going home".
